Events.RelatedDescription: Closed pull request "[tests] Kill adb server before test instrumentation" (#3069) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
This will force adb to restart the server, so we should have fresh adb
for `adb shell am instrument ...`. Hopefully it will help with crashes
of `Mono.Android_Tests` test, we are seeing frequently on Jenkins.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[tests] Increase the emulator RAM size to 3GB" (#3071) at xamarin/xamarin-android

Recently some/many of the tests run out of memory on Jenkins. So lets
try to increase the emulator memory size to see whether it will help.

The emulator is created for every build on CI, like this:

    Using "CreateAndroidEmulator" task from assembly "/Users/builder/jenkins/workspace/xamarin-android/xamarin-android/build-tools/scripts/../../bin/BuildRelease/Xamarin.Android.Tools.BootstrapTasks.dll".

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[d16-2] Add support for deferred builds when the IDE supports them" (#3070) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
In order to take the most expensive target in a DTB (`UpdateAndroidResources`) out
of the DTB, the IDE can monitor design-time builds and schedule a deferred build
to run after the DTB finishes.

When the IDE supports deferred builds, the  `DeferredBuildSupported` will be
true, and in that case, the `DeferredBuild` target will run after the DTB finishes. To
schedule targets to run as part of that deferred build, they need to be added to
the `DeferredBuildDependsOn` property.

Targets can selectively disable themselves on DTBs when the deferred build is
supported by checking for both `'$(DeferredBuildSupported)' == 'true'` and the
`'$(DeferredBuild)' == 'true'` property, which is set for those builds.

The deferred build queuing will be based on the following condition: a regular design
time build was triggered and the targets run were either "Compile" or any target
that contains "DesignTime" in its name (this excludes queuing a deferred build
when a target like `GetFrameworkPaths` or `GetTargetPath` is run in a DTB, for
example).

Note that `Inputs`/`Outputs` on the targets, as well as any `DependsOnTargets`
specified remain the same as before. The effect is that expensive targets that caused
a slow DTB before, can now be scheduled to run *after* the build finishes (this is
when the deferred build is queued).

It's entirely opt-in (if no targets are specified for `DeferredBuildDependsOn`
it will be essentially a no-op run).

Finally, when a regular build starts, the existing deferred build will be waited for
completion before continuing, to ensure no concurrency happens.

The initial `Compile` target is run by the DTB in VS while
skipping the compiler call, at which point the UpdateAndroidResources
should also be skipped when the `DeferredBuildSupported` is `True`.

Subsequently, we run the `DeferredBuild` (or rather, the `UpdateAndroidResources`
which would be run by the `DeferredBuildDependsOn` we append it to)
which should also succeed (it's run with the same global parameters/
properties as the initial DTB).

Finally, we run the normal build, at which point everything should
succeed like before.

If an XVS version that supports this feature is installed, you can turn it on
by setting an environment variable `DeferredBuildSupported=true`. An A/B experiment
or remote setting can also set this value.

Backport of #2636.

/cc @kzu

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Add support for deferred builds when the IDE supports them" (#2636) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
In order to take the most expensive target in a DTB (`UpdateAndroidResources`) out
of the DTB, the IDE can monitor design-time builds and schedule a deferred build
to run after the DTB finishes.

When the IDE supports deferred builds, the  `DeferredBuildSupported` will be
true, and in that case, the `DeferredBuild` target will run after the DTB finishes. To
schedule targets to run as part of that deferred build, they need to be added to
the `DeferredBuildDependsOn` property.

Targets can selectively disable themselves on DTBs when the deferred build is
supported by checking for both `'$(DeferredBuildSupported)' == 'true'` and the
`'$(DeferredBuild)' == 'true'` property, which is set for those builds.

The deferred build queuing will be based on the following condition: a regular design
time build was triggered and the targets run were either "Compile" or any target
that contains "DesignTime" in its name (this excludes queuing a deferred build
when a target like `GetFrameworkPaths` or `GetTargetPath` is run in a DTB, for
example).

Note that `Inputs`/`Outputs` on the targets, as well as any `DependsOnTargets`
specified remain the same as before. The effect is that expensive targets that caused
a slow DTB before, can now be scheduled to run *after* the build finishes (this is
when the deferred build is queued).

It's entirely opt-in (if no targets are specified for `DeferredBuildDependsOn`
it will be essentially a no-op run).

Finally, when a regular build starts, the existing deferred build will be waited for
completion before continuing, to ensure no concurrency happens.

The initial `Compile` target is run by the DTB in VS while
skipping the compiler call, at which point the UpdateAndroidResources
should also be skipped when the `DeferredBuildSupported` is `True`.

Subsequently, we run the `DeferredBuild` (or rather, the `UpdateAndroidResources`
which would be run by the `DeferredBuildDependsOn` we append it to)
which should also succeed (it's run with the same global parameters/
properties as the initial DTB).

Finally, we run the normal build, at which point everything should
succeed like before.

If an XVS version that supports this feature is installed, you can turn it on
by setting an environment variable `DeferredBuildSupported=true`. An A/B experiment
or remote setting can also set this value.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[tests] Kill adb server before test instrumentation" (#3069) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
This will force adb to restart the server, so we should have fresh adb
for `adb shell am instrument ...`. Hopefully it will help with crashes
of `Mono.Android_Tests` test, we are seeing frequently on Jenkins.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "F# records are broken when building with Link SDK and User Assemblies in Debug mode" (#2873) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

1.  Define an F# record type
2. Set the Linking option to SDK and User Assemblies
3. Try to create an instance of the record

If you try this sample out you can see it happening. Click the FAB. 

When set to Link SDK Assemblies Only or None, you will see the record printed in the debug console.

When set to link User Assemblies, it will throw an exception.

I have tried adding the standard Preserve attribute but it hasn't helped.
I also saw errors in my production app that suggested union case constructors were being removed.

Remember to clean / rebuild between runs.

[Test.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/files/3014145/Test.zip)


### Expected Behavior

The record should be constructed normally.

### Actual Behavior

The record crashes the application when trying to access its values.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug] rework Image Renderer to use new image loading code used by buttons" (#6091) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description

Code introduced by #4915 should replace the code in `ImageViewExtensions` for loading bitmap images. 

There are a lot of UI Tests you can use to test this with but Bugzilla51173 is a good one to vet that it all works ok after changes

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Open up the CollectionView implementation on Android" (#6090) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
Pretty much everything in the CollectionView Android implementation is internal and/or sealed. Making these classes accessible would give more room for customizations.

I'm talking about these classes: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/tree/master/Xamarin.Forms.Platform.Android 

I would like to override the ItemsViewAdapter OnBindViewHolder method but in order to do that I basicly have to copy the whole folder in my solution to use my own adapter. If the classes would be public, I could extend from the ItemsViewAdapter and override the required methods in the ItemsViewRenderer.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[iOS] Add missing call to ReloadData on NotifyCollectionChangedAction.Reset" (#6089) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description of Change ###

The iOS adapter for INotifyCollectionChanged is missing a call to `ReloadData` when handling `NotifyCollectionChangedAction.Reset`. This adds the missing call.

### Issues Resolved ### 

- fixes #5793 

### API Changes ###

None

### Platforms Affected ### 

- iOS

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Profiler v11; No man init" (#6087) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody: Start up profiler with manual init code but w/o changing any of the existing init code needed to enable partial init. That's causing UITests to fail and will be submitted piecemeal after I get this in.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "I'm having an timeout issue, specifically a WebException." (#5992) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- ðŸš¨ STOP ðŸš¨ ð—¦ð—§ð—¢ð—£ ðŸš¨ ð‘ºð‘»ð‘¶ð‘· ðŸš¨ -->

<!--
Please fill in the *entire* template below.
The template is designed to avoid unnecessary delays to confirm and fix reported issues. Issues with missing information generally end up with a `need-info` label and take significantly more time to fix. Please help us help you!
For more information see https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-macios/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-&-Suggestions
For support requests use https://www.xamarin.com/support
-->
### Steps to Reproduce

So the issue I'm running into is a WebException (specifically a timeout).

I have been able to narrow it down to the HTTP Client implementation settings in iOS.

- When it is set to **Managed** I don't get the error

- When I set it to **NSUrlSession (iOS 7+)** a timeout exception is being generated after a request has been running longer than 1 minute.

We also tested our json request, using Insomnia, and it took about 5 mins to complete and we got data, but no exception is generated.

I do not have access to the middle tier, just the server logs that get updated.

I know about the HttpClient.Timeout property which we have set for large amount of time, are there any other configuration variables for setting the timeout when needing TLS 1.2?

(The TLS 1.2 is a requirement)

_:: Extra Info That May Be Helpful ::
It looks as though NSUrlSession (iOS 7+) setting forces the native HTTP Client to be used (which has a hard-coded timeout of 60 seconds)_

This was cross posted at Xamarin.Forms before I new where to post.

### Expected Behavior
A HTTP response, specifically a  file (size may vary)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "VisualStudio constantly changes CFBundleIdentifier for Extensions" (#5991) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- ðŸš¨ STOP ðŸš¨ ð—¦ð—§ð—¢ð—£ ðŸš¨ ð‘ºð‘»ð‘¶ð‘· ðŸš¨ -->

<!--
Please fill in the *entire* template below.
The template is designed to avoid unnecessary delays to confirm and fix reported issues. Issues with missing information generally end up with a `need-info` label and take significantly more time to fix. Please help us help you!
For more information see https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-macios/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-&-Suggestions
For support requests use https://www.xamarin.com/support
-->
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create an Extension with the CFBundleDisplayName "My Uploader"
2. Set the CGBundleIdentifier to "com.domain.project.uploader"
3. Save and Close the Solution
4. Open the Solution
5. Open the Extension's Info.plist

### Expected Behavior

The CFBundleIdentifier value is "com.domain.project.uploader"

### Actual Behavior

The CFBundleIdentifier value is "com.domain.project.My Uploader"

### Environment

1.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[apidiff] Use mono-api-[info|html].exe from the mono archive." (#5990) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Closed pull request "[builds] package-ios-bcl and package-mac-bcl aren't parallel safe." (#5967) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
They're not even safe to run sequentially without some manual intervention.

This will be fixed in mono at some point, and we make this parallelized again.
